content: I took a battery of tests before I enlisted in 1970, then I had to take a similar bunch again in the first week or so of basic training. To tell you the truth, I STILL have no idea what each category stands for, but they look like this (The 1st score is what I got at home and the second is the retest in Basic): VE 118/130, AR 108/127, SM 124/108, PA 121/136 ACS 121/96, AI 126/128, MA 123/139, ELI 120/120, GIT 125/124, CI 129/151, ARC 122/- IN 122/143 AE 126/126, EL 121/135 GM 123/117, MM 125/135, CL 120/113 GT 113/129 RC 126/- MOB-1 102, OCT-3 121, DLAT-113, AFQT 85, OQI 113. Now to this day I have no idea what any of this means, but after taking the test in Basic, I was pulled into the Orderly Room and asked if I wanted to go to West Point! ! I told them it would be fine with me but would it make any difference if I was married? That ended that, but these scores put me on the Fast Track to NCO School and Drill Sergeant School right there in Basic Training. So what in the world do all those scores mean??? This message has been edited. Last edited by: greywolfghost, Mon 20 April 2009 06:06 PM Wandering and Wondering

content: The AFQT is important. It determines whether or not you can join the military. The AFQT score is not derived from all portions of the ASVAB. Indeed, the AFQT score is determined from only four areas of the ASVAB: Word Knowledge (WK), Paragraph Comprehension (PC), Arithmetic Reasoning (AR), and Mathematics Knowledge (MK).. The score is computed as follows: The first step is to determine your Verbal Expression (VE) Score. This is done by adding the value of your ASVAB Word Knowledge (WK) Score to the values of your Paragraph Comprehension (PC) Score. This result is then compared to a chart which gives you your scaled VE Score. The formula to derive the AFQT "raw Score" is 2VE + AR (Arithmetic Reasoning) + MK (Mathematics Knowledge). It's important to understand here that the AFQT score is not computed with the AR "Line Score" and the MK "Line Score" that you see on your ASVAB scores sheet. The AR and MK scores shown on the score sheet is "number correct." However, the score used to compute AFQT score is the "weighted score," which takes into consideration the difficulty level of the question. This formula results in the AFQT "raw score," which is then converted into a percentile score. Your score was 85. I'll see if I can find my score...

content: I know that for WWII, there were three different tests give. One for those educated (to be officers), one for those who spoke english, but had little or no education, and one that had symbols for the many immigrants who still didn't know english well (if at all).

Curiosity killed the wolf too You actually did quite well on your ASVAB. I did not have to retake the test in Basic... To this day I do not know why they retest you anyway. So for being the only kid in my Company NOT retaking the ASVAB... I got KP. LOL! You never win in the Army. My "lowest" individual score was 117. Highest was in the 140s. Most hovered about 130 or so. I do know that I was in the 97th percentile group. My mother STILL keeps commenting on that... after 34 years. LOL! Bought was right... I was an Airborne geek in Dress Greens... I was also offered West Point Prep. School (not Westpoint itself). And did not take it... Wonder if I should have taken the offer??? Ancient history now.

I was an Airborne geek in Dress Greens... I was also offered West Point Prep. School (not Westpoint itself). And did not take it... Wonder if I should have taken the offer??? Ancient history now. They just ran the whole company into a place and we took tests for like two days. Because I enlisted, rather than being drafted, I had already taken a similar test. Some scores improved some didn't. Because everyone else was pretty much draftees, they probably didn't have much motivation to do well. I wanted to do as well as possible, because I had enlisted "Armor" and didn't want that to change. The deal about "West Point" was a bit of a shocker. I did have one year of college on an athletic scholarship, but it was anything but stellar, either academically or athletically. That's one of the reasons I decided to enlist. At that point, college wasn't for me. I was getting in too many fights and doing poorly in class. Army during Viet Nam seemed a more natural chose. But I'm still totally puzzled what all these strange acronyms and scores mean - - Wandering and Wondering

content: Those are skills qualification tests. They were supposed to reveal what MOS you'd be good at. I'm not sure about all others, but IN means Infantry and we were told you had to score at least 100 to be considered for any skill field. I did well in all of them and only "failed" one...Infantry. Guess where I ended up? LOL Frankly, I was surprised to even get a score in the one where you listened to dots and dashes over a loud speaker and tried to decode them. I don't think I got any of them right, except for the simple ones such as . or .- But, like you, I was offered West Point, along with a couple of other guys. It was explained to me that I'd have to attend a year of prep school, probably at The Citadel or VMI, then 4 years at the point, followed by a 4 year committment. That's nine years, or nearly half a career. Sadly for the Army, asking me if I wanted to volunteer for nine years while in basic with a Drill Sergeant about half-way up my azz all the time was a bad time to do it.

content: I took a battery of tests before I enlisted in 1970, then I had to take a similar bunch again in the first week or so of basic training. To tell you the truth, I STILL have no idea what each category stands for, but they look like this (The 1st score is what I got at home and the second is the retest in Basic): VE 118/130, AR 108/127, SM 124/108, PA 121/136 ACS 121/96, AI 126/128, MA 123/139, ELI 120/120, GIT 125/124, CI 129/151, ARC 122/- IN 122/143 AE 126/126, EL 121/135 GM 123/117, MM 125/135, CL 120/113 GT 113/129 RC 126/- MOB-1 102, OCT-3 121, DLAT-113, AFQT 85, OQI 113. Now to this day I have no idea what any of this means, but after taking the test in Basic, I was pulled into the Orderly Room and asked if I wanted to go to West Point! ! I told them it would be fine with me but would it make any difference if I was married? That ended that, but these scores put me on the Fast Track to NCO School and Drill Sergeant School right there in Basic Training. So what in the world do all those scores mean??? This message has been edited. Last edited by: greywolfghost, Mon 20 April 2009 06:06 PM Wandering and Wondering

content: The AFQT is important. It determines whether or not you can join the military. The AFQT score is not derived from all portions of the ASVAB. Indeed, the AFQT score is determined from only four areas of the ASVAB: Word Knowledge (WK), Paragraph Comprehension (PC), Arithmetic Reasoning (AR), and Mathematics Knowledge (MK).. The score is computed as follows: The first step is to determine your Verbal Expression (VE) Score. This is done by adding the value of your ASVAB Word Knowledge (WK) Score to the values of your Paragraph Comprehension (PC) Score. This result is then compared to a chart which gives you your scaled VE Score. The formula to derive the AFQT "raw Score" is 2VE + AR (Arithmetic Reasoning) + MK (Mathematics Knowledge). It's important to understand here that the AFQT score is not computed with the AR "Line Score" and the MK "Line Score" that you see on your ASVAB scores sheet. The AR and MK scores shown on the score sheet is "number correct." However, the score used to compute AFQT score is the "weighted score," which takes into consideration the difficulty level of the question. This formula results in the AFQT "raw score," which is then converted into a percentile score. Your score was 85. I'll see if I can find my score...

They just ran the whole company into a place and we took tests for like two days. Because I enlisted, rather than being drafted, I had already taken a similar test. Some scores improved some didn't. Because everyone else was pretty much draftees, they probably didn't have much motivation to do well. I wanted to do as well as possible, because I had enlisted "Armor" and didn't want that to change. The deal about "West Point" was a bit of a shocker. I did have one year of college on an athletic scholarship, but it was anything but stellar, either academically or athletically. That's one of the reasons I decided to enlist. At that point, college wasn't for me. I was getting in too many fights and doing poorly in class. Army during Viet Nam seemed a more natural chose. But I'm still totally puzzled what all these strange acronyms and scores mean - - Wandering and Wondering

content: Those are skills qualification tests. They were supposed to reveal what MOS you'd be good at. I'm not sure about all others, but IN means Infantry and we were told you had to score at least 100 to be considered for any skill field. I did well in all of them and only "failed" one...Infantry. Guess where I ended up? LOL Frankly, I was surprised to even get a score in the one where you listened to dots and dashes over a loud speaker and tried to decode them. I don't think I got any of them right, except for the simple ones such as . or .- But, like you, I was offered West Point, along with a couple of other guys. It was explained to me that I'd have to attend a year of prep school, probably at The Citadel or VMI, then 4 years at the point, followed by a 4 year committment. That's nine years, or nearly half a career. Sadly for the Army, asking me if I wanted to volunteer for nine years while in basic with a Drill Sergeant about half-way up my azz all the time was a bad time to do it.

content: I took a battery of tests before I enlisted in 1970, then I had to take a similar bunch again in the first week or so of basic training. To tell you the truth, I STILL have no idea what each category stands for, but they look like this (The 1st score is what I got at home and the second is the retest in Basic): VE 118/130, AR 108/127, SM 124/108, PA 121/136 ACS 121/96, AI 126/128, MA 123/139, ELI 120/120, GIT 125/124, CI 129/151, ARC 122/- IN 122/143 AE 126/126, EL 121/135 GM 123/117, MM 125/135, CL 120/113 GT 113/129 RC 126/- MOB-1 102, OCT-3 121, DLAT-113, AFQT 85, OQI 113. Now to this day I have no idea what any of this means, but after taking the test in Basic, I was pulled into the Orderly Room and asked if I wanted to go to West Point! ! I told them it would be fine with me but would it make any difference if I was married? That ended that, but these scores put me on the Fast Track to NCO School and Drill Sergeant School right there in Basic Training. So what in the world do all those scores mean??? This message has been edited. Last edited by: greywolfghost, Mon 20 April 2009 06:06 PM Wandering and Wondering

content: The AFQT is important. It determines whether or not you can join the military. The AFQT score is not derived from all portions of the ASVAB. Indeed, the AFQT score is determined from only four areas of the ASVAB: Word Knowledge (WK), Paragraph Comprehension (PC), Arithmetic Reasoning (AR), and Mathematics Knowledge (MK).. The score is computed as follows: The first step is to determine your Verbal Expression (VE) Score. This is done by adding the value of your ASVAB Word Knowledge (WK) Score to the values of your Paragraph Comprehension (PC) Score. This result is then compared to a chart which gives you your scaled VE Score. The formula to derive the AFQT "raw Score" is 2VE + AR (Arithmetic Reasoning) + MK (Mathematics Knowledge). It's important to understand here that the AFQT score is not computed with the AR "Line Score" and the MK "Line Score" that you see on your ASVAB scores sheet. The AR and MK scores shown on the score sheet is "number correct." However, the score used to compute AFQT score is the "weighted score," which takes into consideration the difficulty level of the question. This formula results in the AFQT "raw score," which is then converted into a percentile score. Your score was 85. I'll see if I can find my score...

I told them it would be fine with me but would it make any difference if I was married? That ended that, but these scores put me on the Fast Track to NCO School and Drill Sergeant School right there in Basic Training. So what in the world do all those scores mean???
reply: GWG, is there something to that old saw about "great minds" running in similar paths? or is this just a matter of "old vets' minds" running amok? I had run across my DA 20 (from a few years earlier than yours) with those same/similar cryptic codes and asked the same question: DA form 20 question "I took the Army battery of tests at the Cleveland, Ohio induction center in '62. I recently came across a copy of that form, DA 20, Enlisted Qualification Record. Column 23 - APPTITUDE TESTS and 24 - OTHER TESTS show some 26 FORMS/TESTS and the numerical score for each. Does anybody have any idea what those criptic abreviations like VE-8Q or MA-6BC (Ill be thrilled to post the entire list for anybody who remembers) mean?? Some of the codes are pretty clear, phy fit, but what the numbers mean is a complete mystery" btw, My scores are only one number for each code (only tested once) but additional code was typed in beside each: VE-8Q -130 AR-4BC - 136 PA-2BC - 143 MA-6BC - 134 ACS-1Q - 124 ARC-1 - 138 SM-2BC - 125 AI-4BC - 122 EL-2BC - 140 Then there's another colume of codes and scores plus a colume headed occ.: CO - A- 141/B- 137 EL - 138 GM - 131 MM - 126 CL - 126 GT - 133 RC - 135 IN - 129 AE - 118 "Wiki had this - but what does it mean??"..Exactly! I'll keep a watch on this thread so, if you get any leads, please post them. Color me curious.

Yeh, that's the new testing and scoring. All of the scores are below 100, so it has to be a new system. I've only got one score below 100, so it must be on some ancient, weird scale. I was just hoping some of the older folks (fossils like me) might have a clue what the possible scores were, and what all the acronyms stand for - - I can guess, but that doesn't mean much... Curiosity killed the wolf too You actually did quite well on your ASVAB. I did not have to retake the test in Basic... To this day I do not know why they retest you anyway. So for being the only kid in my Company NOT retaking the ASVAB... I got KP. LOL! You never win in the Army. My "lowest" individual score was 117. Highest was in the 140s. Most hovered about 130 or so. I do know that I was in the 97th percentile group. My mother STILL keeps commenting on that... after 34 years. LOL! Bought was right... I was an Airborne geek in Dress Greens... I was also offered West Point Prep. School (not Westpoint itself). And did not take it... Wonder if I should have taken the offer??? Ancient history now.

They just ran the whole company into a place and we took tests for like two days. Because I enlisted, rather than being drafted, I had already taken a similar test. Some scores improved some didn't. Because everyone else was pretty much draftees, they probably didn't have much motivation to do well. I wanted to do as well as possible, because I had enlisted "Armor" and didn't want that to change. The deal about "West Point" was a bit of a shocker. I did have one year of college on an athletic scholarship, but it was anything but stellar, either academically or athletically. That's one of the reasons I decided to enlist. At that point, college wasn't for me. I was getting in too many fights and doing poorly in class. Army during Viet Nam seemed a more natural chose. But I'm still totally puzzled what all these strange acronyms and scores mean - - Wandering and Wondering

content: Those are skills qualification tests. They were supposed to reveal what MOS you'd be good at. I'm not sure about all others, but IN means Infantry and we were told you had to score at least 100 to be considered for any skill field. I did well in all of them and only "failed" one...Infantry. Guess where I ended up? LOL Frankly, I was surprised to even get a score in the one where you listened to dots and dashes over a loud speaker and tried to decode them. I don't think I got any of them right, except for the simple ones such as . or .- But, like you, I was offered West Point, along with a couple of other guys. It was explained to me that I'd have to attend a year of prep school, probably at The Citadel or VMI, then 4 years at the point, followed by a 4 year committment. That's nine years, or nearly half a career. Sadly for the Army, asking me if I wanted to volunteer for nine years while in basic with a Drill Sergeant about half-way up my azz all the time was a bad time to do it.
